The CIA prevented the Daleks capturing Project Revenant by arranging its destruction just as they boarded the facility. (AUDIO: Desperate Measures)

The Daleks pursued Time Lord agent Aymor in his search for an erased superweapon, following him to the starship Theseus which they boarded. (AUDIO: The Starship of Theseus) Cardinal Ollistra subsequently lured a Dalek fleet to a trap at the planet where the Theseus crashed. (AUDIO: Echoes of War [+]Matt Fitton, The Eighth Doctor: Time War: Volume One (The Eighth Doctor: Time War, Big Finish Productions, 2017).) The Daleks attacked the Time Lord facility on the Moon of Tenacity, deploying a reversal wave through the Tenacity System to erase its defences. They pursued the Doctor's TARDIS from Tenacity, battling a Time Lord fleet over Jedris where it eventually crashed. (AUDIO: The Conscript, One Life)

After being alerted by an agent that the Time Lords had occupied it and were building an arsenal of rockets, the Daleks invaded Derilobia. They captured Commander Carvil's TARDIS, however it self-destructed after he was exterminated and the distraction it caused enabled the Time Lord forces to evacuate. (AUDIO: The Lords of Terror)

A Dalek force led by the Overseer occupied The Planet and enslaved the Ogrons. The Overseer conducted numerous experiments on the Ogrons, including retrospectively adding them to past Dalek battles. When the Doctor and the Twelve investigated the Planet, the Overseer created Doctor Ogron by mixing the Doctor with an Ogron. Doctor Ogron led a revolt against the Daleks, during which a task force arrived to relieve the Overseer of command as its experiments had been deemed an abomination to Dalek purity. The Doctor, the Twelve and Bliss were also captured (AUDIO: Planet of the Ogrons) and taken to a prison camp on Sangrey for interrogation, though they managed to escape. (AUDIO: In the Garden of Death) Based on information from the Twelve's interrogation, the Admiral led a Dalek expedition to Uzmal to find the legendary Ourashima. Battling resistance forces led by the Doctor and Ollistra, the Daleks found the Ourashima but were unable to communicate with it. To prevent it falling into the Time Lords' hands, the Admiral sacrificed the entire taskforce to kill it. (AUDIO: Jonah)

The Dalek Time Strategist led a Dalek mission to Thellian to acquire a genetic modifier created by Shonnath, the last of the Helixara, that she had used to prevent herself from being erased from history by the Time Lords. The Daleks were unable to land on the planet, so sent a duplicate first who arranged for them to transmat down. The Eighth Doctor, Bliss and the Sixth Tamasan beat the Daleks to the genetic modifier and escaped with it. (AUDIO: Fugitive in Time [+]Roland Moore, The Eighth Doctor: Time War: Volume Three (The Eighth Doctor: Time War, Big Finish Productions, 2019).)

The Daleks, with the exception of the Time Strategist which escaped through a rift, were erased from history by the Valeyard who turned their own superweapon against them on Grahv. (AUDIO: The War Valeyard) The Time Strategist used dimensional engineering and a parallel universe version of Davros to restore the Daleks. The simulacra Davros attempted to assert his authority over the Daleks, however the Strategist arranged the restoration of the Emperor. The Emperor had the simulacra put in stasis, believing he may be of use one day. (AUDIO: Palindrome, Restoration of the Daleks [+]Matt Fitton, The Eighth Doctor: Time War: Volume Four (The Eighth Doctor: Time War, Big Finish Productions, 2020).)

The Daleks employed a Time Destructor in order to gain the upper hand in the war, destroying Polymos and creating a temporal shockwave which affected systems from the Farflung Rift to the Wolf's Heart Nebula. (PROSE: Natural Regression)

A skirmish between Dalek and Time Lord forces devastated the planet Drakkis throughout its history. (AUDIO: The Sontaran Ordeal)

The Daleks began feeding the Time Lords intelligence in order to lure them into an ambush on Skaro. Their plan succeeded, with a fleet of Battle TARDISes assaulting Skaro, only to fall victim to a new Dalek superweapon. However, the War Doctor and Petrella survived the ambush and were able to warn the Time Lords of the Dalek superweapon. (COMIC: Ambush)

The Daleks had dealings with a crime boss, Jarred McKenzie, on Unity. He revealed he had found a TARDIS, prompting the Daleks to invade the planet fully to exterminate the Time Lords it belonged to. They found Romana alone and attempted to exterminate her (AUDIO: Unity) however she was saved by Irving Braxiatel. The Daleks pursued her associates, including Narvin, to a resistance base which they attacked. A Hunter Dalek subsequently followed Narvin to Micallon but failed to capture him. (AUDIO: Dissolution) Romana was later captured when the Daleks ambushed Braxiatel's TARDIS. (AUDIO: Homecoming)

The Dalek Emperor and Time Strategist launched a gambit to seize Gallifrey using null zone technology. Their saucer easily bypassed Kasteroborus' defences using this method but required time to recharge to land on Gallifrey. During this time, the Daleks fended off Time Lord counterattacks using the null zone technology and used Romana as a spokesperson to the Time Lords. Their plan failed when Narvin and War Livia Caralis detonated a Battle TARDIS by the null zone power source, with the Emperor and Strategist escaping before the saucer was destroyed. (AUDIO: Homecoming)

During the year A10%?, the Daleks attacked Marinus. Working with the Voord, the War Doctor defended the planet with a chronic tripwire, which aged the Daleks in an attacking flying saucer to dust. (COMIC: Four Doctors [+]Paul Cornell, Titan summer events (Titan Comics, 2015).)

Late in the War, the Daleks assembled a huge fleet of timeships to invade Gallifrey. The fleet was intercepted by the Time Lords, who deployed a Time Destructor to annihilate it. The War Doctor replaced the assigned Time Lords and fired it himself, barely escaping with his life. (AUDIO: The Innocent)

A Dalek agent, Lara Zannis, breached the time lock around Earth, arriving in 1961 Berlin, pursued by the War Doctor. She used the Shadow Vortex to enable the Time Strategist to invade Earth. The Daleks hoped to rewrite history by preventing the Doctor's companions existing, however the War Doctor un-did the invasion by using his TARDIS to collide the Shadow Vortex with its past self pre-activation, erasing Lara in the process. (AUDIO: The Shadow Vortex)

The Dalek Time Strategist was captured by Sontarans seeking to join the Time War led by Fesk. He was held captive with Cardinal Ollistra on Rovidia, with the Daleks unable to rescue him due to the Sontarans' temporal defences powered by the Eternity Cage. The War Doctor infiltrated Rovidia and deactivated the Cage, which enabled the Daleks in orbit to descend on the planet. (AUDIO: The Eternity Cage) Whilst the Daleks destroyed the Rovidian fleet, the Time Strategist took the opportunity to order a Dalek agent, Heleyna, who was onboard the TARDIS that the Doctor and Ollistra had escaped in, to use the Cardinal to open that TARDIS' link to the Eye of Harmony. A Dalek Assault Squad was sent to use the link to reach Gallifrey, however the Doctor used the TARDIS' reconfiguration system to delete the Eye of Harmony chamber, wiping them out. (AUDIO: Eye of Harmony) The Time Strategist subsequently led a fleet in pursuit of the Doctor and Ollistra, first to a space station and then to Beltox. Their initial assault on Beltox was defeated, enabling the Doctor and Ollistra to escape again, however the Daleks returned and destroyed the planet. (AUDIO: Pretty Lies) The Daleks followed them to Grend, where their invasion was defeated by a squadron of Battle TARDISes and the forces of the Lady of Obsidian, Leela. (AUDIO: The Lady of Obsidian)

The Time Strategist made contact with the Enigma, a being from another dimension, and convinced it to erase the Time Lords, turning Gallifrey into a Dalek world. The Enigma had doubts however so reverted things back shortly afterwards, and was finally convinced by the War Doctor, Ollistra and Leela to stay out of the War. It expelled all the Daleks in its dimension. (AUDIO: The Enigma Dimension)

Several Daleks from late in the War travelled back in time to attack a munitions factory in the Mountain of Serenity where Gallifreyan children were being kept safe, with the intent of killing them before they could take part in the War. The War Doctor evacuated the children, and Tahl sacrificed himself by detonating explosives in the mountain, causing a collapse that buried the Daleks. (PROSE: The Stranger [+]Gary Russell, Heroes and Monsters Collection (Heroes and Monsters Collection, 2015).)

At one point, the Daleks managed to amass an enormous fleet and launch an overwhelming assault on Gallifrey. Facing annihilation, and with no other options left, Cardinal Ollistra had Councillor Voltrix open a rift in space, releasing the Great Vampires, which destroyed the Dalek fleet. (COMIC: The Bidding War)

On the last day of the Time War, the Daleks broke the defences of Arcadia, Gallifrey's second city, (TV: The Last Day [+]Steven Moffat, 50th Anniversary arc 50th Anniversary Prequel 2 (2013).) and invaded it. Unable to to breach the Capitol's sky trenches, the Dalek fleet surrounded and bombarded Gallifrey. The War Doctor planned to use a weapon known as the Moment to wipe out both the Time Lords and the Daleks. However, this option was not taken, and "all thirteen" incarnations of the Doctor teamed up together to hide Gallifrey and the Time Lords in an unknown pocket universe, leaving the Dalek fleet to wipe itself out in its own crossfire. In outward appearances, the result of this action was the same as if the Moment had been used: Gallifrey disappeared and the Daleks were (mostly) destroyed. (TV: The Day of the Doctor [+]Steven Moffat, 50th Anniversary Specials (BBC One, 2013).)

The Ninth Doctor incorrectly assumed that "the entire Dalek race" had been "wiped out" by the Time War. (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) There were, however, numerous exceptions.

In his book on the end of the Last Great Time War, the Doctor's future incarnation the Curator acknowledged the unlikelihood of so few Daleks as later encountered by the Doctor having survived the blast that ended the Time War, no matter how great an explosion that was. He stated that his personal belief was that upon witnessing, at the moment of what should have been their final victory, the skies of Gallifrey being filled with a veritable swarm of versions of their worst enemy the Doctor, most of the Daleks who did not die were struck with such unimaginable amounts of fear that they ran way in terror to parts unknown, and were "probably still running now". (PROSE: The Day of the Doctor [+]Steven Moffat, adapted from The Day of the Doctor (Steven Moffat), Target novelisations (Target Books, 2018).)

The first of the Time War survivor Daleks encountered by the Doctor fell through time and crashed like a meteorite "on the Ascension Islands". The Dalek lay in its burning crater for three days, screaming the entire time, before it was retrieved. Its weapon systems inactive and its outer armour heavily damaged, the Dalek was sold at private auction and passed through several hands over the next fifty years. In 2012 it was acquired by billionaire Henry Van Statten who nicknamed it Metaltron. It sent a distress signal to the Ninth Doctor and his companion Rose Tyler. Upon Rose's touch it absorbed a small amount of her DNA, using the artron energy of a time traveller's DNA to revivify itself. Breaking out of confinement, it went on a rampage, only to realise that its absorbing Rose's DNA had caused it to begin mutating into "something different... something new", a Dalek-human hybrid with the swirling thoughts and emotions, and the reluctance to kill, of a human. Refusing to become impure, and unable to cope with the independence of mind that was coming to it, it ultimately self-destructed. (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).)

Toward the end of the Last Great Time War the Daleks sent a time capsule to 70 AD Earth in order to spread the Dalek Factor amongst the humans to use humans to build more Daleks as back-up for the Time War. The capsule's engine failed during the trip and the Dalek inside ejected, crashing on Earth. It died shortly thereafter and released only a small amount of the Dalek Factor, leading to only one in five hundred million humans having it. The Tenth Doctor discovered the dead shell which had been a Roman exhibit until the British threw it into some caves and gave the Dalek gunstick to Frank Openshaw. However, the unearthing of the Dalek activated the Dalek Factor in Kate Yates who developed a Dalek personality and touched the dead casing, causing her Dalek life-force to grow a new Dalek in the casing from the casing's databanks. The Dalek hunted down Frank and killed him to retrieve its gun arm and then went on a rampage, killing many people before finding Kate. When the Doctor arrived, the Dalek offered the Doctor a deal: if he gave it a way to travel in time and space, it would spare Earth and go to another planet to rebuild its race and spread across the universe. If the Doctor refused, it would destroy the Earth. With no way to destroy the Dalek, the Doctor agreed to the deal and provided it with an old Time Ring he had stored in the TARDIS. The Dalek revealed its plan to be to travel to the year 500 million where humanity was peaceful and had no knowledge of the Daleks. There he'd get Kate to convince the humans to give it the materials it needed to rebuild its race. As the Dalek prepared to exterminate the Doctor, Rose reached out to Kate's human side, trying to get her to fight her Dalek side by reminding her of the good of humanity. After a mental struggle, Kate's human side regained control and she used her Dalek knowledge to set the Time Ring to self-destruct. The Dalek, trapped by Kate in a force field to protect the Doctor during her mental struggle, was caught in a warp implosion caused by the Time Ring self-destructing and was atomised. The Dalek Factor in Kate then deactivated without the Dalek there to stir it up and she lost everything the Dalek Factor had given her including her increased intelligence and Dalek personality. (PROSE: I Am a Dalek [+]Gareth Roberts, Quick Reads (BBC Books, 2006).)

A group of surviving Daleks unleashed their proton cannon on 22nd century Earth, resulting in all life becoming intangible (unable to touch solids). The plan was that, unable to eat, humans would soon just waste away from the Earth and the Dalek survivors would rebuild war ships and attack. The Tenth Doctor used the Krikoosh to reach the proton cannon. Unhurt by the Daleks' rays, the Doctor made some adjustments and turned the weapon against the Daleks. The humans became solid again and the Daleks with their 'protective' shields were left intangible. The Daleks judged this an unacceptable outcome and self-destructed. (COMIC: Extermination of the Daleks)

One Dalek, trapped in the Matrix under Gallifrey, was encountered by the Twelfth Doctor after Gallifrey's restoration. The Doctor speculated it had been there since the Cloister Wars. It begged to be exterminated when it was ensnared by the Cloister Wraiths. (TV: Hell Bent [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 9 (BBC One, 2015).)

The Dalek Emperor barely survived the "inferno", and fell through time in his damaged flagship. Damaged, but rebuilding slowly, the Emperor influenced the Fourth Great and Bountiful Human Empire as a cover for his plans. (TV: The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) He used the Jagrafess and the Editor as puppets in circa 199,909. (TV: The Long Game [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005)., Bad Wolf [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) It rebuilt the Dalek race using human cells to create an army of just about half a million Daleks. It also built 200 flying saucers containing more than 2000 Daleks each. (TV: Bad Wolf [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) The Emperor, having recreated the Dalek race, saw itself as an immortal god, and so was literally worshipped by the new Daleks. These and other religious concepts such as blasphemy were new to Dalek psychology. (TV: The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).)

The Emperor's pawn, the Controller, hated her masters and transmatted the Ninth Doctor and his allies to the Game Station to help defeat them. When he discovered the fleet and the new Daleks, (TV: Bad Wolf [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) the Doctor realised that the Daleks hated their own existence since they were partially human. Additionally, they had been driven mad by hundreds of years of solitude. Jack Harkness led a small human resistance to stop the Daleks. Thanks to Rodrick, the humans on Floor 000 didn't help him. On Floor 500 The Doctor decided to create a Delta Wave to destroy the Daleks, but didn't have enough time to refine it so that it could distinguish between humans and Daleks. The Doctor decided to turn his chance down to use the delta wave to kill humans and Daleks alike, even though the Daleks had just bombed Earth heavily, wiping out entire continents. The Emperor thought he was victorious, but he and his entire fleet were atomised by Rose Tyler after she had absorbed the energies of the time vortex and became the Bad Wolf. (TV: The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).)

The Cult of Skaro had been created by the Dalek Emperor and were given names. Dalek Sec was the leader of the cult, and the others were named Dalek Caan, Dalek Thay and Dalek Jast. They were "above and beyond the Emperor himself" and were designed to "think as the enemy thinks" and to imagine new ways of survival as well as new ways of killing. (TV: Doomsday [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).) By one account, the Cult was formed before the Time War and were just four ordinary Daleks originally. Dalek Sec was the Dalek Commander of the Seventh Incursion Squad sent to wipe out the remnants of the Mechanoids on Magella which they succeeded in doing. Dalek Caan was an Attack Squad Leader of the Thirtieth Assault Group. Dalek Thay was the Commandant of Station Alpha, the most secret Dalek research facility. Dalek Jast was the Force Leader of the Outer Rim Defensive Battalion. After doing this, they were promoted to become the Cult of Skaro. (PROSE: Birth of a Legend) A group of researchers later claimed the Cult had been formed during the war. (PROSE: Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe [+]George Mann, Justin Richards and Cavan Scott, Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe (Ebury Publishing, 2017).)

The Cult, foreseeing a disastrous end on the Daleks' side by the end of the Time War, built a Void Ship for themselves, which allowed them to hide away outside the universe, in the Void between parallel realities. They had acquired a Time Lord prison ship, the Genesis Ark, which contained millions of Daleks captured during the war. (TV: Doomsday [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).) They leaked back into 21st century Earth, inadvertently allowing five million Cybermen from a parallel world to follow in the "wake" of their Void Ship and invade the Earth. (TV: Army of Ghosts [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).) After emerging from the Void Ship, the Cult held Rose Tyler and Mickey Smith hostage while Dalek Thay confronted the Cybermen. Thay turned down an offer of an alliance from the Cybermen, prompting the Cyber-leader to declare war on the Daleks, while the Cult, confident in the ability of even one Dalek to destroy the "inferior" species, stated that he deemed the wiping out of the Cybermen to be nothing more than "pest control".

Sec then oversaw the pulling of the Ark out of hibernation with the touch of a time traveller, allowing the liberated Daleks to fight the Cybermen (as well as human Torchwood One personnel) for dominion over the Earth in the Battle of Canary Wharf. Through the efforts of the Tenth Doctor, however, the majority of these Daleks were sucked back into the Void, with the only the four members of the Cult of Skaro themselves managing to escape through an emergency temporal shift. (TV: Doomsday [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).)

The Cult emerged in 1930 in New York City, where their first concern was to breed new Dalek embryos. However, they soon abandoned them to die in the sewers, as "their flesh was too weak". This failure led Dalek Sec to determine that the Daleks' obsession with purity and supremacy had brought them to near-extinction, and that the only way for the Daleks to survive was by forcing them to evolve. Sec thus created the Human-Daleks, even going so far as to splice his own body with that of a human ally of theirs, Mr Diagoras. To do so, the Cult infiltrated the construction of the Empire State Building and set up a Transgenic Laboratory beneath it, (TV: Daleks in Manhattan [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007).) from which they planned to use Dalekanium placed on the mast as an energy conductor for gamma radiation from a solar flare to power the Final Experiment.

Despite the arrival of the Tenth Doctor and Martha Jones, the Daleks' Invasion of Manhattan began to unfold, only for Sec's new human emotions to begin to change his vision for their plans. The other three Daleks ruled that Sec had gone too far and had betrayed the Dalek ethos; they stripped him of his authority and eventually killed him. Their attempt to make an army out of Sec's Dalek-Humans was foiled by the Tenth Doctor and Martha Jones, after the Doctor had agreed to work with Sec to make the kidnapped humans in the Experiment into hybrids that were even more humanlike than Sec. Sec sacrificed himself to save the Doctor's life from Thay, Jast and Caan, who then ordered their Dalek-Humans to take aim at him. The hybrids, however, questioned their orders and refused to fire. The Doctor revealed that his getting in the way of the lightning-strike had caused his Time Lord DNA to mix with the human-Daleks and that gave them freedom. Still stunned, Thay and Jast killed a few human-Daleks but were killed in the process. Caan, declaring the Human-Daleks a "failure", exterminated the new species. The Doctor confronted Caan and offered help, claiming not wanting to cause another genocide after seeing one already, but Caan once again used a temporal shift to escape. (TV: Evolution of the Daleks [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007).)

Caan, seeing no better way to bring the Dalek race back to its former glory, broke the time lock on the Last Great Time War to rescue Davros from the jaws of the Nightmare Child. Davros then used his own body cells to recreate the Dalek race and rebuilt a Dalek Fleet of two hundred ships. (TV: The Stolen Earth [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).)

The planet-sized station known as the Crucible was the flagship of the New Dalek Empire. The Supreme Dalek was created and locked Davros and Caan inside the Vault while guarded by Vault Daleks. The new fully-formed Empire transported 27 planets to the Medusa Cascade and took control over the planets. In their attack on Earth, they took many humans aboard their ships, and wiped out any resistance that they met. (TV: The Stolen Earth [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).) During the Dalek invasion, a Dalek was observed by a young Adelaide Brooke as it passed by her house. This Dalek spared her life, flying off to space. This inspired her to go to space, not for revenge, but to explore. The Tenth Doctor believed it recognised her as a fixed point in time. (TV: The Waters of Mars [+]Russell T Davies and Phil Ford, Doctor Who Autumn Special 2009 (BBC One, 2009).)

The new Empire planned to use the 27 planets in conjunction with the Crucible's energy source to power a reality bomb created by Davros who intend to make the destruction of all existence and allow the Daleks to be the sole inhabitants and masters of the universe. The Supreme Dalek made an arrangement with Davros; the creator of the Daleks would ensure their domination of the universe if they allowed him to live. The plan failed by the interference of the DoctorDonna, who closed off all of the Z-Neutrino energy relay loops of the reality bomb by using an internalised synchronous back-feed reversal loop, locked the Daleks' weaponry in a self-replicating energy blindfold matrix through macrotransmission of a K-filter wavelength and interfered with the Daleks' systems with a trip stitch circuit-breaker in the psycho-kinetic threshold manipulator.

Deciding the Dalek Empire was a threat too great for the universe, the Meta-Crisis Tenth Doctor maximised the Dalekanium power feeds and blasted them back, executing every Dalek around them and destroying the entire fleet. The destruction of the Void by the reality bomb, which through Donna and the Meta-Crisis Doctor's interference, was reversed through dimensional retroclosure, (TV: Journey's End [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).) though the Daleks who were sucked into the Void were still be destroyed, with only a handful of Cybermen being able to escape with stolen Dalek technology like the Dimension Vault. (TV: The Next Doctor [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who Christmas Special 2008 (BBC One, 2008).) Rose Tyler claimed that "even the Void was dead", (TV: Journey's End [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).) while the Tenth Doctor said that a "greater battle" than the one that locked the Daleks and Cybermen into the Void rose up, which was "so great that everything inside the Void perished". (TV: The Next Doctor [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who Christmas Special 2008 (BBC One, 2008).)

A trio of drones from the New Dalek Empire, (PROSE: Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe [+]George Mann, Justin Richards and Cavan Scott, Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe (Ebury Publishing, 2017).) survived its fall in their flying saucer, falling through time to 1941.

There, the trio picked up the trace of the last surviving Progenitor, which contained pure Dalek DNA, which they intended to create new Daleks with which to restore their race. However, as their DNA was so mangled as to be "unrecognisable as Dalek" to the Progenitor, they were forced to start a scheme called the Ironside Project and created an android named Edwin Bracewell to claim they were his inventions and two of the three Daleks pretended to be ironsides for the British Army during World War II to ensure Winston Churchill would contact the Eleventh Doctor to trick him into delivering his testimony to the Progenitor. Despite their cover blown, the Daleks successfully obtained the Doctor's testimony and returned to their ship to commence their plan. The Doctor used a Jammie Dodger to fool them into thinking it was a TARDIS self-destruct. To counter this, the Daleks activated a beacon to turn the lights of London on to allow German bombers to destroy the city. Five new, larger Daleks were created, with pure DNA and a new colour-coded rank. The Supreme Dalek told the old Daleks they were impure, which they accepted and they allowed themselves to be disintegrated with no resistance. The new Daleks discovered the Doctor's deception and that the TARDIS self-destruct was fake. The Doctor told Danny Boy to destroy the ship after he destroyed the beacon. The Daleks threatened to destroy the Earth with the Oblivion Continuum inside Bracewell unless the Doctor called off his attack. He complied and returned to Earth to disarm the bomb. After the bomb was disarmed, the new Daleks escaped in a time corridor to rebuild their empire based on the New Dalek Paradigm. (TV: Victory of the Daleks [+]Mark Gatiss, Doctor Who series 5 (BBC One, 2010).)

Following their escape, the Daleks discovered the lost Time Lord artefact, the Eye of Time, allowing them to alter time as they saw fit. The Daleks returned to Skaro, rebuilt their capital city of Kaalann, appointed a new Dalek Emperor and began rebuilding their Empire. In this new timeline, they killed every member of the human race. However, the Eleventh Doctor and Amy undid these events, leaving Earth unconquered and Kaalann still abandoned. (GAME: City of the Daleks [+]Phil Ford, The Adventure Games (BBC Wales Interactive, 2010).)

The Dalek Supreme led an attack on the SS Lucy Gray to recover the Daleks' lost Time Axis. The Eleventh Doctor defeated them by firing their ship into the sun. (GAME: Return to Earth [+]Oli Smith, Deep Silver (2010).) The Dalek ship escaped by making a random jump several hundred years into the past. The Daleks attempted to force the Doctor to fix their ship by attaching his TARDIS to their ship; the Doctor escaped and used his TARDIS to fling their ship into a black hole. (GAME: Evacuation Earth [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

A Scientist Dalek sent an alien family plummeting through time and space to collect all the Time orbs. The Scientist recruited many Strategist Daleks and Drones. It also recruited big armies of Cybermen and Silurians as a distraction for the Eleventh Doctor and Amy. (GAME: The Mazes of Time [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

At the beginning of the 40th century, the Daleks began another war with humanity which continued into the 41st century. The Eleventh Doctor and Amy encountered a group led by the Chief Strategist who had been sent on a mission to find a Dalek mutant being experimented on by a scientist who tried to make them less aggressive creatures. The Daleks referred to this mutant as "the Abomination". They attacked and destroyed Earth's top secret space station, Station 7, and chased the survivors to the planet Strantana below. After slaughtering all resistance, they finally found the Abomination in a hidden base, but it escaped its container and disabled the base reactor's safety measures.

An explosion destroyed the base, the Daleks, and all the Dalek ships that had landed on the planet. The Doctor, Amy and Jay, an SSS officer, watched from a safe distance. The Dalek mission was a failure but the war continued. They had agents working in the SSS. The Abomination secretly survived the explosion, but the Doctor remained certain there was no such thing as a good Dalek. (COMIC: The Only Good Dalek [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

The Daleks joined the Pandorica Alliance to imprison the Eleventh Doctor in the Pandorica in 102 to save the universe. (TV: The Pandorica Opens [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 5 (BBC One, 2010).) As the Doctor was not responsible for the Total Event Collapse as they thought, the Daleks, along with almost the rest of the universe, were destroyed, leaving only two Stone Daleks, one of which hindered the Doctor and his companions' efforts to save the universe in 1996. Nevertheless, they were successful and the whole of reality, including the Daleks, were restored. (TV: The Big Bang [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 5 (BBC One, 2010).)

The Doctor had an encounter with the Daleks during which they exterminated Albert Einstein's toothbrush. (TV: Death Is the Only Answer [+]The Children of Oakley Junior School, BBC Three (2011).)

Searching for information on the Silence before going to what he assumed was his death, the Doctor found a badly damaged Supreme Dalek and used it to look up information on the Silence. Shortly afterward, the Doctor was seemingly killed at Lake Silencio in 2011, (TV: The Wedding of River Song [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 6 (BBC One, 2011).) but the Daleks, correctly, believed their foe was still alive. (TV: Asylum of the Daleks [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 7 (BBC One, 2012).) Missy claimed that a Dalek learned of the Doctor's supposed death from a Headless Monk and then told a Draconian, who then told her. (AUDIO: The Bekdel Test)

Led by a new Emperor Dalek, the Daleks planned to remove Gallifrey from existence and become the new Lords of Time. They used a piece of the Eternity Clock to put a time lock around a large part of London in 2106. Once they perfected their time lock technology, they planned to use it to put temporal bubbles around other planets, making them unstoppable. The Eleventh Doctor and River Song infiltrated the Emperor's Flagship and managed to take back the piece of the Clock. (GAME: The Eternity Clock [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

During the reign of the New Paradigm, (PROSE: Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe [+]George Mann, Justin Richards and Cavan Scott, Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe (Ebury Publishing, 2017).) a small contingent of bronze Daleks were sent on a mission to travel through Earth's history and analyse how humans made war so that weaknesses could be found and exploited in future conflicts with the Daleks. They called this the Dalek Project. The Eleventh Doctor encountered these Daleks in the First World War in 1917 where he sent their ship crashing to the ground by ramming a plane into it. The remaining Daleks were destroyed by the combined armies of the war who had formed a very brief alliance to defend themselves. The Dalek saucer remained underground for one hundred years before it was found and accidentally reactivated by a team of archaeologists. The Eleventh Doctor arrived in time to save them and connected the ship up to a power line, overloading the Daleks. He called this "unfinished business". It was governed by the Dalek Foundation, with the planet Carthedia of the Earth Alliance acting as a head of state. However, the Daleks were unable to activate the Cradle and so they sent an anonymous message in the form of a hypercube to the Doctor's TARDIS with the intention of manipulating him into activating the Cradle instead. The Doctor's investigations resulted in shock when he learned the Daleks were considered a force for good and he was placed on trial while trying to convince the citizens of Carthedia that they were evil, which the Daleks had declared a hate crime. He was put on trial by the Dalek Litigator, who was really the Dalek Time Controller posing as a law enforcer, and when he pleaded guilty in a failed attempt to anger the Dalek and was sentenced to imprisonment, he escaped off-planet with three orphaned children, Sabel, Jenibeth and Ollus Blakely, whose parents, Terrin and Alyst, had killed themselves to prevent the Daleks from obtaining the information on the Cradle they possessed.

After learning more about the Cradle on the desert planet of Gethria and losing Jenibeth, the Doctor tried to spark a revolution on Sunlight 349 to cause the collapse of the Dalek Foundation but he could not gather the necessary support. The Dalek Litigator arrived and subjected the Doctor to another public trial. Sabel and Ollus were taken away from the Doctor's care and he was exiled from the Sunlight Worlds. However he returned to Gethria 90 years in the future and encountered an elderly Jenibeth who had been transformed into a Dalek puppet after the Daleks took her prisoner as a child. The Dalek Time Controller arrived and forced the Doctor to activate the Cradle but Jenibeth's childlike mind allowed her to resist her conditioning and she fired on the Daleks, destroying numerous drones and forcing the Time Controller to retreat and the Doctor set the Cradle to self-destruct.

Before the Cradle exploded, it reverted the Sunlight Worlds to how Jenibeth remembered them as a child, as well as turning her and her siblings back into children and recreating their parents, although their memories were reverted too. The Daleks abandoned the plan. (PROSE: The Dalek Generation)

In an alternate timeline created by the Black Guardian, in which the First Doctor never left Gallifrey and instead became Lord President, the Daleks had amassed an enormous empire that even the Time Lords feared. This timeline was erased when the Seventh Doctor acquired the Key to Time, on the instructions of the White Guardian. (COMIC: Time & Time Again)

In one timeline in which the First Doctor's TARDIS never landed on Kembel, the Daleks successfully developed the Time Destructor and embarked on an uncontested campaign of conquest through space. After reaching the Third Galaxy, they annihilated the planet Baralda intent on forcing the swift surrender of neighbouring Urbinia for use of its population as slave labour. The ensuing crisis pitched the Daleks against the First and Second Doctors, and in the absence of a meaningful surrender, the Dalek Supreme opted to destroy the planet. However, the Second Doctor averted the timeline by preventing the initial collision which had sent the First Doctor to Urbinia instead of Kembel. (AUDIO: Daughter of the Gods)

In an aborted timeline, the War Master used the Anti-Genesis codes to travel from the Last Great Time War to Skaro during the Thousand Year War, where he killed Davros (AUDIO: From the Flames) and infiltrated the Kaled Scientific Elite to create his own race of Daleks. (AUDIO: The Master's Dalek Plan [+]Alan Barnes, Anti-Genesis (The War Master, Big Finish Productions, 2019)., Shockwave) In this timeline, the Daleks successfully conquered the universe, but gradually developed a resentment of their creator, (AUDIO: He Who Wins [+]Nicholas Briggs, Anti-Genesis (The War Master, Big Finish Productions, 2019).) as the Daleks had with Davros in the original timeline. (TV: Genesis of the Daleks [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 12 (BBC1, 1975). et al.) Ultimately, these Daleks were erased from existence in a combined effort from the Master's future self, a parallel universe Master, and the Dalek Time Strategist, as the Master's rewriting of the Daleks' history threatened to erase all of creation. (AUDIO: He Who Wins [+]Nicholas Briggs, Anti-Genesis (The War Master, Big Finish Productions, 2019).)

In an alternate timeline where John Hart was the King of England, Hart had Torchwood One open the Void Ship. Thus, the Daleks destroyed Torchwood One and the majority of the home counties. (AUDIO: The Death of Captain Jack)

In an alternate timeline where Rassilon and the Cyberiad allied to conquer all of time and space, the Cybermen conquered Skaro and erased the Daleks from history. The Daleks were restored when the Twelfth Doctor and Rassilon used the Eye of Harmony on Gallifrey to restore the original timeline. (COMIC: Prologue: The Fifth Doctor, Supremacy of the Cybermen)

In a number of timelines scavenged by Sibling Same and Sibling Different to create the Paradox TARDIS, the Daleks fused with the Bad Wolf entity, causing metal copies of Rose Tyler to populate all of time and space. In addition, some of the components of the Doctor's TARDIS that the duo stole from the timelines they explored were scarred with energy fire from Daleks. (PROSE: The Paradox Moon)

In an aborted timeline, the Master of a parallel universe attempted to use the Daleks of N-Space to destroy the entropy wave, a representation of the Master of N-Space's final incarnation, but the Daleks failed and were completely destroyed. This timeline was eventually erased after the entropy wave consumed several of the N-Space Master's incarnations, including Missy, thereby creating a paradox. (AUDIO: Masterful)

In a parallel universe created by the Quantum Archangel, the Daleks were the Enemy in the War in Heaven. (PROSE: The Quantum Archangel [+]Craig Hinton, BBC Past Doctor Adventures (BBC Books, 2001).)

The Dalek Emperor once summoned Daleks from a parallel universe for assistance in conquering Mutter's Spiral. These Daleks, however, were appalled by the actions of their counterparts, who they termed "Enemy Daleks" as they sided with the remnants of the Earth Alliance against the Dalek Empire. (AUDIO: Project Infinity [+]Nicholas Briggs, Dalek Empire (Big Finish Productions, 2002)., Dalek Empire II: Dalek War)

The Thaleks existed in the universe of another Doctor. (AUDIO: Auld Mortality, PROSE: The Innocents)

In the Unbound Universe, the Daleks split into two factions after the disappearance of their creator, Davros. One Dalek faction remained loyal to Davros and left Skaro to search for him, and the other went renegade and began an interstellar empire, encountering the Doctor on several occasions and attacking Earth in 1972. The loyalists eventually returned to Skaro to protect the Thals from the Quatch, the species responsible for the devastation of Skaro. The Doctor and Alistair Lethbridge-Stewart arrived and, after discovering the true purpose of the Daleks' return home, helped the Thals and Daleks defend against the Quatch. The Doctor discovered Davros was working with the Quatch and persuaded him to turn on them by revealing their role in Skaro's devastation. After the Quatch's defeat, the Daleks and Thals decided to live in peace together on Skaro, with Alistair staying to assist. (AUDIO: Masters of War [+]Eddie Robson, Doctor Who Unbound (Big Finish Productions, 2008).)

The Fourth Doctor once theorised the absence of the Daleks in some alternate universes as an explanation for realities in which the Krotons, Quarks and Ogrons respectively emerged as dominant powers. Indeed, a leader of the Ogron Confederation of Planets was unfamiliar with the Daleks. (COMIC: The Lost Dimension)

The Skaro Degradations were Daleks from alternate universes whose creation points had been intercepted by the Daleks of N-Space. They were used by the N-Space Daleks during the Last Great Time War. (PROSE: Engines of War [+]George Mann, BBC New Series tie-in novels (BBC Books, 2014).)

Using the powers of the quantum harvester, Dorothy Bell once observed a parallel universe where the Tenth Doctor was chased by a Dalek heavily resembling an Egyptian sarcophagus. (COMIC: Old Girl)

In the Warrior's universe, Sarah Jane Smith convinced the Doctor to destroy the incubation chamber only for an already active prototype Dalek to both kill her and Harry Sullivan and fatally wound the Doctor, only for him to transported back to Gallifrey before it could deal the killing blow. Enduring despite the Doctor's actions, the Daleks discovered the abandoned Time Ring. Joining with the Kaleds and Thals, the Daleks became part of the Unified Skaroan Alliance and reverse engineered the Time Ring to become a temporal power, waging a time war against Gallifrey. (AUDIO: Dust Devil, Aftershocks)

The Daleks were best-known as a warlike race who waged war across whole civilisations and with races all over the universe. (TV: The Daleks [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 1 (BBC tv, 1963-1964)., Doomsday [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).) When the Eleventh Doctor was on the Dalek Asylum he considered the Daleks the most advanced warrior race in the universe, (TV: Asylum of the Daleks [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 7 (BBC One, 2012).) and the Twelfth Doctor later concurred that the middle of a Dalek war zone was the deadliest place he knew. (TV: The Pilot [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 10 (BBC One, 2017).)

Although Daleks proudly proclaimed that they had "no concept of elegance" (TV: Doomsday [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).) and the One in a Million Dalek's willingness to protect the perishable beauty of flowers was seen as an aberration by his Emperor, (COMIC: Shadow of Humanity [+]unclear authorship, The Daleks comics (City Magazines, 1966).) the Thals knew that the Daleks' forefathers had been "great thinkers and philosophers". (TV: The Daleks [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 1 (BBC tv, 1963-1964).) Though they did not sing, (AUDIO: Jubilee [+]Robert Shearman, Main Range (Big Finish Productions, 2003).) the Daleks were still known to write poetry. (PROSE: The Also People [+]Ben Aaronovitch, Virgin New Adventures (Virgin Books, 1995).) Some of the more elaborate Dalek battle cries had an almost poetic quality about them (for example, "Advance and Attack! Attack and Destroy! Destroy and Rejoice!") (TV: The Chase [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 2 (BBC1, 1965).) and repetition of words such as "Predict! Predict! Predict!" (TV: The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) and "Explain! Explain! Explain! (TV: Journey's End [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).)

As a means of entertainment, the Dalek Survival Guide claimed that the Daleks occasionally enjoyed watching re-runs of great Dalek victories, but stated that their true passion was for reconnaissance; a Dalek would go to any lengths to gather new information, and they would often put themselves at great risk to do so. The guide presented an image of a Dalek using its sucker arm to take a copy of The Complete Works of Shakespeare; (PROSE: Dalek Survival Guide [+]Justin Richards, et al., BBC Books (2002).) in an alternate timeline where they ruled over Earth, the Daleks claimed to have a fondness for the works of William Shakespeare, but the Eighth Doctor understood this to be a lie. (AUDIO: The Time of the Daleks [+]Justin Richards, Main Range (Big Finish Productions, 2002).) According to a diary kept by a human time traveller, the Daleks observed a holiday known as "Extermination Day" every other day. (PROSE: Time Traveller's Diary [+]Chris Farnell, BBC Children's Books (2020).)

More "disgustingly" (in the words of the Eleventh Doctor), the Daleks viewed pure hatred as beautiful and worth preserving even at a great cost, which was the reason for the existence of the Dalek Asylum, where Daleks so blithely hateful that they presented a danger to their own people were kept. (TV: Asylum of the Daleks [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 7 (BBC One, 2012).) Earlier in Dalek history, the Dalek Prime Strategist implemented a plan that defeated an entire Mechonoid army on Skaro. When the Emperor of the Restoration looked for a word to describe the plan, the Strategist suggested "effective," but the Emperor instead called it "beautiful." (WC: Day of Reckoning [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

The Tenth Doctor believed that music was "all just noise" to the Daleks, an observation which inspired him to temporarily repel a few Daleks by amplifying a radio's harmonies into a screech that was already painful to human ears, but seemed downright unbearable to the Daleks. (TV: Evolution of the Daleks [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007).)

Due to their frequent defeats by the Doctor, he became a legendary figure in Dalek culture and mythology. They had standing orders to capture or exterminate the Doctor on sight, and were occasionally able to identify him despite his regenerations. The Daleks knew the Doctor as the "Ka Faraq Gatri", meaning the "Bringer of Darkness" or "Destroyer of Worlds". (COMIC: Bringer of Darkness [+]Warwick Gray, DWMS comic stories (Marvel Comics, 1993).) Indeed, after the Doctor had shattered the Daleks' ambition to wipe out all of creation save for themselves using a reality bomb, an enraged Davros screamed to the Doctor that he "named [him], forever, the Destroyer of Worlds!!…". (TV: Journey's End [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).)

The Ninth Doctor told the human-born Daleks he met on Satellite Five that "the ancient legends of the Dalek homeworld" referred to him as "the Oncoming Storm". (TV: The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) The Doctor was also referred to as the Predator of the Daleks. Shortly before the destruction of the Dalek Asylum, Oswin erased all knowledge of the Doctor from every Dalek's memory. (TV: Asylum of the Daleks [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 7 (BBC One, 2012).) However, the Daleks regained their memory of the Doctor from Tasha Lem. (TV: The Time of the Doctor [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who Christmas Special 2013 (BBC One, 2013).) Remembering their foe drove the Prime Minister of the Daleks insane. (PROSE: Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe [+]George Mann, Justin Richards and Cavan Scott, Dalek: The Astounding Untold History of the Greatest Enemies of the Universe (Ebury Publishing, 2017).)

The Daleks had also been a vital part of the Doctor's growth, as he made it his mission to combat evil in the universe after meeting the Daleks during his First incarnation. (TV: Into the Dalek [+]Phil Ford and Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 8 (BBC One, 2014).) Though the Doctor sometimes thought he had totally defeated his nemeses, the Tenth Doctor was angered by the belief that, while he would lose everything, the Daleks always survived. (TV: Daleks in Manhattan [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007).) After the years of combat between the time traveller and the Dalek race, Davros stated that the Doctor had "slaughtered" billions of Daleks. (TV: The Witch's Familiar [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 9 (BBC One, 2015).)

The Daleks saw the Doctor as their greatest enemy. (TV: The Chase [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 2 (BBC1, 1965)., Victory of the Daleks [+]Mark Gatiss, Doctor Who series 5 (BBC One, 2010)., Evolution of the Daleks [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007).) Even though he once referred to the Master as his archenemy, (TV: The Deadly Assassin [+]Robert Holmes, Doctor Who season 14 (BBC1, 1976).) the Doctor also described the Daleks as his greatest foes (COMIC: Defender of the Daleks [+]Jody Houser, Time Lord Victorious release order (Titan Comics, 2020).) and archenemies, going as far as to view them as the greatest sin in the universe. (TV: Victory of the Daleks [+]Mark Gatiss, Doctor Who series 5 (BBC One, 2010).) Similarly, during his Twelfth life, the Doctor stated Davros, the creator of the Daleks, was his arch nemesis. (TV: The Magician's Apprentice [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 9 (BBC One, 2015).) When talking about the Daleks to Ace, the Seventh Doctor's voice developed a hard edge that unsettled her. (PROSE: Illegal Alien [+]Mike Tucker and Robert Perry, adapted from Illegal Alien, BBC Past Doctor Adventures (BBC Books, 1997).)

According to Clara Oswald, the Doctor was scared of the Daleks, which made their companion's fear increase as well. (PROSE: The Companion's Companion) The War Doctor once reflected that he feared what the Daleks represented more than the Daleks themselves, (AUDIO: The Enigma Dimension) whereas the Ninth Doctor was mortified upon seeing a Dalek after the Time War, screaming in fear before relishing in its agony. (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) While talking with Rusty, the Twelfth Doctor stated that, if he was helped in any way, the Daleks would be hurt. (TV: Twice Upon a Time [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who Christmas Special 2017 (BBC One, 2017).) The Thirteenth Doctor stated that encounters with the Daleks were personal. (TV: Resolution [+]Chris Chibnall, Doctor Who New Year Special 2019 (BBC One, 2019).) The Daleks did not make up part of the Fifth Doctor's anti-Morbius alliance, but he had a nightmare where they offered their help. (PROSE: Warmonger)

Daleks had little individual personality and a strict hierarchy. They were conditioned to obey a superior's orders without question, even if these orders resulted in pain or death. (AUDIO: The Curse of Davros [+]Jonathan Morris, Main Range (Big Finish Productions, 2012).) Indeed, Dalek Jast told a Dalek-human that Daleks did not question orders, (TV: Evolution of the Daleks [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007).) whilst Dalek Thay maintained that Daleks did not take orders from non-Daleks, (TV: Doomsday [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).) with another Dalek stating that Daleks did not answer human questions. (TV: The Stolen Earth [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).)

The most fundamental feature of Dalek culture and psychology was an unquestioned belief in the superiority of the Daleks. Other species were either to be exterminated or enslaved, and then exterminated when no longer necessary. The default directive of a Dalek was to destroy all non-Dalek life forms. (TV: The Power of the Daleks [+]David Whitaker, Doctor Who season 4 (BBC1, 1966)., Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005)., et al.) They interestingly tended to project a similar mindset on other species; they found it difficult to understand that humans sometimes destroyed members of their own species, (TV: The Power of the Daleks [+]David Whitaker, Doctor Who season 4 (BBC1, 1966).) and several Daleks observed that there was something admirable about the Doctor's hatred of the Daleks and intent to wipe them out completely, even if they found it monstrous that this exterminating intent was directed at them. (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005)., Asylum of the Daleks [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 7 (BBC One, 2012)., Into the Dalek [+]Phil Ford and Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 8 (BBC One, 2014).)

Because of their belief in their species' superiority, (TV: Daleks in Manhattan [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007).) Daleks even regarded Daleks whose DNA deviated from their race's standard genetic makeup as their enemies and worthy of extermination, considering these deviant units impure. (TV: Revolution of the Daleks [+]Chris Chibnall, Doctor Who New Year Special 2021 (BBC One, 2021).) The civil war between the Renegade and Imperial Daleks was an example of this. Each faction considered the other a perversion despite the relatively minor differences. (TV: Remembrance of the Daleks [+]Ben Aaronovitch, Doctor Who season 25 (BBC1, 1988).) This belief also meant that Daleks were intolerant of such "contamination" even within themselves. (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005)., The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005)., Evolution of the Daleks [+]Helen Raynor, Doctor Who series 3 (BBC One, 2007)., AUDIO: The Mutant Phase [+]Nicholas Briggs, Main Range (Big Finish Productions, 2000).) Despite this, Daleks felt offended by exterminating their own "divine hatred", and deviant Daleks would sometimes instead be sent to the Dalek Asylum, should their hatred be deemed pure enough. (TV: Asylum of the Daleks [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 7 (BBC One, 2012).) At other points in their history, however, they showed no hesitation to exterminating those they deemed impure. In fact, when a cloned recon Dalek noted it could be purified thanks to its remaining Dalek DNA, a Dalek commander responded by ordering its destruction, proclaiming that extermination was the only purification the Daleks offered. (TV: Revolution of the Daleks [+]Chris Chibnall, Doctor Who New Year Special 2021 (BBC One, 2021).)

Another result of this superiority complex was their complete ruthlessness. This was due to genetic modifications made to the original Kaled mutants by Davros. It was because of this that it was nearly impossible to negotiate or reason with a Dalek, and it was this single-mindedness that made them so dangerous.

Their reliance on logic and machinery was a weakness, albeit one that they recognised. Daleks considered illogical actions impossible. (TV: Destiny of the Daleks [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 17 (BBC1, 1979).) However, one Dalek went out of its way to say its species did not rely on logic to make decisions, stating they instead relied on hatred and their own power, which it deemed to be superior sources of power. (GAME: All Aboard!) The Daleks also transferred emotions from other life-forms in at least two instances, in one case humans, having refined the Human Factor with the help from the Second Doctor to create humanised Daleks. (TV: The Evil of the Daleks [+]David Whitaker, Doctor Who season 4 (BBC1, 1967).) In another instance, they refined slyness from the Xxarqon, cruelty from the Tentrax and insane hatred from the Glarosus. (COMIC: Doctor Who and the Dogs of Doom [+]John Wagner and Pat Mills, DWM Comics (Marvel Comics, 1980).)

One unintentionally humanised Dalek occurred after it used Rose Tyler's DNA to regenerate after sustaining injuries, involuntarily developing positive feelings. Its traditional Dalek psychology remained, however, and it ultimately self-destructed in disgust. The emotional capacity of Daleks was limited to largely negative emotions (hate being chief among them), as "human" emotions such as compassion and sentimentality were considered by them to be weaknesses. However, they were capable of comprehending these emotions, and often used them to exploit their enemies. A prime example occurred with the lone Dalek in Henry van Statten's vault; while talking with the Ninth Doctor, the Dalek chose its words carefully, hoping to goad the Time Lord into initiating a physical attack on the chained mutant. Later, the Dalek played on an unwitting Rose Tyler's feelings of pity and compassion, leading her to touch its battered casing and restore energy to the near-dead Dalek. (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).)

Additionally, the Daleks used the greed of Theodore Maxtible to make him their ally. However, Daleks never formed permanent alliances; once their allies outlived their usefulness, they were usually exterminated on the spot. (TV: The Daleks' Master Plan [+]Terry Nation and Dennis Spooner, Doctor Who season 3 (BBC1, 1965-1966)., The Evil of the Daleks [+]David Whitaker, Doctor Who season 4 (BBC1, 1967)., AUDIO: The Mutant Phase [+]Nicholas Briggs, Main Range (Big Finish Productions, 2000).) A Death Squad Dalek claimed that Daleks did not need allies, (TV: Revolution of the Daleks [+]Chris Chibnall, Doctor Who New Year Special 2021 (BBC One, 2021).) and a Exxilon Dalek claimed that Daleks did not require "the co-operation of inferior creatures." (TV: Death to the Daleks [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 11 (BBC1, 1974).)

The Ninth Doctor claimed that Daleks were incapable of any emotion except hate, (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) and later that they had "removed all [their] emotions", though he speculated there remained "one little spark" of fear somewhere in their DNA. (TV: The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) However, many Daleks were shown displaying a wider range of emotion, Missy claimed that Daleks used emotions such as hate and anger to fuel their weapons. (TV: The Witch's Familiar [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 9 (BBC One, 2015).) The Metaltron claimed that Daleks did not fear. (TV: Dalek [+]Robert Shearman, adapted from Jubilee (Robert Shearman), Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) However, the Cult of Skaro displayed fear of the Tenth Doctor, physically recoiling at the mention of his name, (TV: Doomsday [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 2 (BBC One, 2006).) and another Dalek begged River Song in terror for its life. (TV: The Big Bang [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 5 (BBC One, 2010).) The Daleks were also capable of anticipation, preferring to wait for their victims to run before exterminating them. (TV: The Magician's Apprentice [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 9 (BBC One, 2015).) The Twelfth Doctor believed that if a Dalek's cortex vault were to be deactivated, then it might be possible for a Dalek to experience a wider range of emotions. (TV: Into the Dalek [+]Phil Ford and Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 8 (BBC One, 2014).) When discussing the comparatively less aggressive mindset of the Daleks who had fought in the Thal-Dalek battle, the Seventh Doctor and Bernice Summerfield pondered that several centuries without victims to exterminate had allowed the Daleks' better nature to influence their attitudes. (AUDIO: The Lights of Skaro [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.)

According to the Tenth Doctor, Daleks were brilliant scientists and engineers. (PROSE: Prisoner of the Daleks [+]Trevor Baxendale, BBC New Series Adventures (BBC Books, 2009).) According to K9 Mark II's files, the Daleks' chief characteristics were "ruthlessness, cunning and implacable resolve". (AUDIO: The Dalek Contract [+]Error: Code 2 - no data stored in variables, cache or SMW.) Davros considered the Daleks to be single-minded, determined and ruthless. According to the Eleventh Doctor, the Daleks were "the worst thing in all creation". They had "no conscience, no mercy [and] no pity". He claimed that "hate" looked like a Dalek and that "the Daleks [were] death". (TV: Victory of the Daleks [+]Mark Gatiss, Doctor Who series 5 (BBC One, 2010).) The Seventh Doctor declared the Daleks "irredeemably evil", although the Grey Man disagreed. (PROSE: Falls the Shadow [+]Daniel O'Mahony, Virgin New Adventures (Virgin Books, 1994).) While he originally thought there was no hope in the prospect, it was the Twelfth Doctor's hope that he could turn Rusty "good", thereby opening the door to turn all Daleks into a force for good. (TV: Into the Dalek [+]Phil Ford and Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 8 (BBC One, 2014).)

The Sontaran Subliminal Education Matrix's entry on the Daleks acknowledged that they and the Sontarans shared a bloodlust and a will to bend all opposition to their "iron rule", however, it maintained that the Sontarans were motivated by honour and their own "superiority" whilst the Daleks were motivated by their hatred for all other life forms which was characterised as a dishonourable "weakness" and "sickness" that dwarfed the Sontarans' own animosity for the Rutans. It did, however, observe that the Daleks were "the right height". (PROSE: A Soldier's Education [+]Dave Rudden, Twelve Angels Weeping (2018).)

Daleks were prone to making blunt, absolute statements and would respond sincerely even to jestful comments. (TV: Eve of the Daleks [+]Chris Chibnall, Doctor Who New Year Special 2022 (BBC One, 2022).) The Black Dalek Leader insisted that Daleks did not make mistakes. (TV: "Volcano") Rusty believed that Daleks did not have souls. (TV: Into the Dalek [+]Phil Ford and Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 8 (BBC One, 2014).) One Dalek, after exterminating a group of fake singing Daleks, insisted that "Daleks do not sing." (AUDIO: Jubilee [+]Robert Shearman, Main Range (Big Finish Productions, 2003).) During the Planetary Relocation Incident, a Dalek stated that Daleks did not accept apologies. (TV: The Stolen Earth [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 4 (BBC One, 2008).) A Dalek prisoner claimed that Daleks did not capitulate or plead. (PROSE: Prisoner of the Daleks [+]Trevor Baxendale, BBC New Series Adventures (BBC Books, 2009).) A Defence Drone stated that the Daleks did not "make jokes". (TV: Revolution of the Daleks [+]Chris Chibnall, Doctor Who New Year Special 2021 (BBC One, 2021).) Several Dalek Executioners stated that Daleks were patient, supreme, unstoppable, "not fair", "not worried", and that they did not "store stuff" or have friends or managers. (TV: Eve of the Daleks [+]Chris Chibnall, Doctor Who New Year Special 2022 (BBC One, 2022).) A Red Supreme Dalek told Georgy Gold that Daleks did not plead. (COMIC: Liberation of the Daleks [+]Alan Barnes, DWM Comics (Panini Comics, 2022-2023).)

The Daleks were willing to kill their creator, Davros, on a number of occasions. (TV: Genesis of the Daleks [+]Terry Nation, Doctor Who season 12 (BBC1, 1975)., Resurrection of the Daleks [+]Eric Saward, Doctor Who season 21 (BBC1, 1984).) However, as recounted by Jack Harkness, the Daleks repeatedly realised they needed their creator, specifically requiring his knowledge, genius, expertise, and creativity. (WC: Monster File: Davros [+]Justin Richards, Captain Jack's Monster Files (2008).) Davros stated that, thanks to a genetic defect he failed to remove, the Daleks showed respect and mercy towards him. This was why they allowed him to siphon their life energy to sustain himself while he was dying. (TV: The Witch's Familiar [+]Steven Moffat, Doctor Who series 9 (BBC One, 2015).)

As noted above, the Daleks created by the manipulation and mutation of human genetic material by a demented Dalek Emperor were religious fanatics. They worshipped the Emperor as their god and even had a concept of blasphemy. Normal Daleks had no religion, other than their fanatic belief in their own supremacy, (TV: The Parting of the Ways [+]Russell T Davies, Doctor Who series 1 (BBC One, 2005).) with some Daleks accordingly claiming there was no God.
